entry.title: The Pelican Brief
entry.summary:
Enough with trying to roll my own static site generator. Let's give Pelican a go.

pip install pelican markdown
mkdir test-pelican
cd test-pelican
pelican-quickstart

I answered the site generation questions as follows.

> Where do you want to create your new web site? [.]
> What will be the title of this web site? Jeff Caulfield
> Who will be the author of this web site? Jeff Caulfield
> What will be the default language of this web site? [en]
> Do you want to specify a URL prefix? e.g., http://example.com   (Y/n)
> What is your URL prefix? (see above example; no trailing slash) http://jeffcaulfield.com
> Do you want to enable article pagination? (Y/n)
> How many articles per page do you want? [10]
> What is your time zone? [Europe/Paris] Europe/London
> Do you want to generate a Fabfile/Makefile to automate generation and publishing? (Y/n)
> Do you want an auto-reload & simpleHTTP script to assist with theme and site development? (Y/n)
> Do you want to upload your website using FTP? (y/N)
> Do you want to upload your website using SSH? (y/N)
> Do you want to upload your website using Dropbox? (y/N)
> Do you want to upload your website using S3? (y/N)
> Do you want to upload your website using Rackspace Cloud Files? (y/N)
> Do you want to upload your website using GitHub Pages? (y/N) y
> Is this your personal page (username.github.io)? (y/N) y

I then copied across content from my existing website and modified the metadata to use Title case, keeping all articles under the content folder instead of nesting folders by year, and started the development server.

./develop_server.sh start

I made a number of changes to pelicanconf.py to use my own theme, which I created by adapting the simple theme, taking some hints from the notmyidea theme. Getting it pushed to github.io was a bit of a pain. In the end I combined information from several sources and decided on using a submodule to accomplish what I wanted. Not the cleanest approach, but it seems to work.

My procedure for updating this website involves running make publish followed by cd output && git commit && git push.

entry.title: Gilding the Lily
entry.summary:
I tried a variety of static site generators on my way to rebuilding my personal website: hexo, hugo and sculpin, just to name a few. These all seem very complicated for what they purport to be, and definitely overkill for my needs.

Eventually, I stumbled across embellish. It's written in Python. It's very lightweight. It doesn't require a ton of files to get started. I was able to get something off the ground quickly without becoming bogged down in excessive detail. Very nice.

That said, I feel that there's some "fat" that could yet be trimmed. I don't understand the need to use Haml for templates when Jinja is fine on its own. I'm not using compiled assets (CoffeeScript, Sass and so forth), although that's not to say that I might not want to do so later on. I'd like the command-line to auto-detect "site.yaml" when it is present. I'd also like to remove or at least rename the "site.cache" file.

At the same time, there are a few small but important features that are missing. A sitemap and a syndication feed in Atom and/or RSS format should be a given. A "draft" mode for content in progress also seems essential. Pagination would be useful for large archive indexes. Finally, I'd like a simple way to add site-specific extensions (Python scripts) to customise the render process, if at all possible.

This all seems acheivable. I think I'll call it gild as in "gilding the lily" in keeping with the theme of embellishment.

What could possibly go wrong?
